captions.text: [CAR ENGINE]
[MUSIC]

The 435i is lower, stiffer, and
generally sportier than
the 3 Series.

But the biggest news is probably
the name, which to me
is plain wrong.

It's like renaming Coca Cola,
Vegetable Bum Water.

Actually, it's not quite
that bad, as you know.
But you get the gist.

The 3 Series coupe was
a motoring staple.
It didn't need renaming.

After several aborted attempts
to record a [INAUDIBLE]

camera on the roads around
Lisbon, I'm resorting to
voice-over.
It just wasn't happening.
It's a man thing.

Please turn left
in 100 metres.
I need to be rid of you.

This is a curious car, because
at first it seems ridiculous

that a 306-horsepower BMW coupe
that will smash up to 62

miles an hour in 5.1 seconds,
could come across as a bit
uninteresting.

This one is at least fitted with
the optional 8-speed auto

which is, as I have to keep
saying, is plain brilliant.

Optional electric dampers ride
well in comfort, a little bit
spiky in spots.

The 435i is so fast and
discreet, you wonder if BMW

could have made it any more
ordinary looking--

except for those weird arrow
bits on the front wings, which
look like seals' ears.

The problem here is
a familiar one--

the 435i is so accomplished,
you wonder if it borders on
the boring.

So I wandered into the faded
glory of Estoril.

And couldn't really hide my
disappointment at the
normalness of it all.
I know the M4--

now that sounds completely
wrong to my ears--

will be the hot shoe, but a
300-horsepower, rear-drive BMW

should make you tingle
just a bit.
Shouldn't it?

The steering is quick, the car
changes direction beautifully,

the motor does that
BMW growly thing.

But it's just not
that enlivening.
Nor was the message from BMW.

The pre-track briefing
stipulated, no drifting.
Talk about red rag to a bull.
So here we are at Estoril.
Four laps.
And, curiously, in the briefing
at the end, no drifting.

I'm a bit like a 14-year-old
being told not to smoke, when
someone says, no drifting.
It's a bit, red rag to a bull.

So I'm going to try and resist
drifting, cause it's not big,
and it's not clever.

But this is a rear-wheel
drive BMW.

And what are rear-wheel drive
BMWs for, if not to kind of
play with the back of the car?
Isn't that the whole point?

Otherwise you just buy
an Audi, don't you?
I don't know.
We'll discuss that later on.
What have we got here then?

We have a strange car, because
this is 10,000 pounds more

than an M135i, and yet,
it has less torque.

So I'm not quite sure what
they're trying to do in
performance terms.

The chassis immediately
feels better balanced.

Longer wheelbase, everything
about it just feels a little
bit more grown up.

And I really like the
rear axle location.

The rear axle is far better
located in this car than it is
in the 1 Series.

It deals with this torque
without thinking about it.
Steering--

really nice and quick,
actually.
Very impressed by that.
Brake pedal-- firm.

Why am I doing this
on the track?

Who's going to come and do
a track in their 435i?
Not many people.

We're just on a normal
street tire.

But even so, the performance
of the car.

A few years ago, this would have
been just about bordering
on supercar performance.
It's incredible.
Transmission--
love this 8-speed ZF.

I know I crap on about it,
but it's just so good.

Matched with this turbo-charged
straight-six, it

works brilliantly, really
brilliantly.

Remember, no drifting
please, no drifting.
and I mean, no drifting.
[CAR ENGINE]
Okay, no drifting.

BMW, I mean, it's a bit like
leaving plates of cake out at

tea-time, and saying,
don't eat it.

Your cars are brilliant
at going sideways, so
I'm going to do it.
Morally wrong not to.
Really nice chassis.

I get the hint of what
an M3 might be like
now, it's pretty exciting.

Because this structure
is stiff.

Everything about it
is high quality.

Can a BMW be called
a 4 Series?

That's a philosophical
question.

That's a deeply philosophical
question, isn't it?
I'm not sure it can, actually.

I struggle with the
group four.

It doesn't sound quite
right to me.
[CAR ENGINE]

This guy has more performance
than most of the people that
buy it will ever need, OK?
It really does.
But--

and there is a "but" here, as
I cruise into the pit lane.

The "but," for me, is that
despite driving so well, and

being so fast, this is quite
an ordinary-feeling car.
You know?

It doesn't feel that special
to me at all.
Well over 40 grand in the UK.

Cabin is quite ordinary
3 Series.

The whole thing is
quite ordinary.

Leaves a lot of space
for the M3.
A lot of space for the M3.

And so, underneath all that
gloss and perfection, there

really is a very good
performance car.

One that keeps BMW well ahead
of its German rivals in this
particular sector.

And, as if to acknowledge the
fact that it might need some

added spice, BMW will be
offering a load M Performance

modifications as aftermarket
parts--

suspension, brakes, a locking
differential, and a power kit

that adds 34 horsepower, and
37 foot pounds of torque,

taking it back up to kind
of M135i levels of poke.

The only problem is, they
didn't let us drive one.
Just remember--
no drifting.
[CAR ENGINE]
[LAUGHTER]
[BEEP]
you.

Of course we're going to do
some drifting, you know?
I mean, it's a BMW, isn't it?

title: BMW 435i on Road and Track - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

BMW is miles behind Audi in terms of overall looks and, particularly, 
interior design. Bimmers drive well, sure, but the next A5/A4 will murder

the direct competitor to this 435i, has a more powerful engine - and a 
supercharged one at that: no turbo lag.﻿

comments.text:
Dinan Stage 1 tune, good for 360 hp and 392 ft-tq, and does NOT void your 
warranty.  And before some idiot says something about those numbers not 
being wheel horse power, we ALL already know those are not wheel horse 
power numbers... but neither are the stock "300 300" BMW says the car has. 
 So, we're comparing, apples to apples.  Another quick note, the stock 
engine may be closer to 320hp...  Either way, if you can afford a $60,000 
435i spending $2,000 for the Dinan tune should be an easy decision.﻿

comments.author: Dom Watson

comments.text:
Chris you have a point, why make a 4 series? Over time, the 4 series might 
overshadow the 3 series. I believe that BMW knows that and it is such a 
shame. However, I hope the 4 series does not ruin the 3 series or 5 series. 
What becomes the purpose of the 3 series? The 4 series demotes the 3 series 
and transcends it; while making one question the reason to buy a 5 series 
(because of the size). I understand BMW is trying to fill a gap, but in 
reality they never needed to. Despite the awkward placement and creation of 
the 4 series, I am curious to see how the car develops throughout the 
future. I don't want to be right on my judgement of the 4: I hope to see 
the 3,4, and 5 develop their own special traits that make them separate and 
unique amongst each other.﻿

comments.text:
Why hate? Behave yourself, do not call other people idiots.

How do you know what I can and what I cannot afford? Yes I can perfectly 
afford a nicely optioned c63, and that would be my second car, 3-rd in the 
family.

And Honda makes very nice cars for their purpose, though I am in the market 
for a different car.

Finally, this is a place where people can ask questions. Some people who 
have had experience on the matter (i.e. owned or tested a car) may want to 
share their opinion. If you can't and don't want to offer such, just move 
along.
comments.author: Nick Swampsurfer

comments.text:
Chris and all of you guys,

So what do you think about today's options of a high performance RWD sedan?

Let's sum it up:
- C63 AMG is superb but for its lagging MCT and low MPG. If not for the 
maddening MCT (as per reviews) I would have bought it already.
- new 2015 C63 AMG is not coming very soon, and probably it will come with 
the same MCT.
- M3 - should be very good, but IMO the bumpers are too busy and it looks 
too purposely (flashy?) sporty, at the expense of style. 435i looks so much 
cleaner and thus better. Am I alone here?
- 435i - looks great, but a sedan would be better for me, and I would not 
mind 4.5sec acceleration. Would not mind the manual. Though the 8-speed ZF 
shifts without lagging.
- m235i - ditto.
- 335i - kinda bland and not that fast.
So, should I grab the current C63? Which is a better car? Thoughts? Better 
make a decision before they take me to a mental house :D﻿
comments.author: Nick Swampsurfer

comments.text:
YO DUMBASS, the PRE-SAFE system that has been stock on MBs since 2007 
contains a collision detection system, as well as a bracing system that 
will detect if the accident is inevitable, and raise all unblocked windows, 
tighten seat belts, and tighten side bolsters on the seats to protect the 
driver and occupants. Attention assist are monitoring cameras and sensors 
that detect drowsiness and alert you. Stop talking about shit that you know 
nothing about you chink faggot.

Yo dumbass show me how you configured your BMW 435i to $69,165 USD? also

comments.author: sdajjd

comments.text:
yeah, the old 3-series coupe had a "sleekness" this car lacks in my 
opinion. But i'm still getting one :P
comments.author: Edward Orlando

comments.text:
Not sure what I think of this new car. I had my heart set on getting the 
new M3, but im not liking the new 3/4 series styling.
comments.author: sebastianpatten

comments.text:
problem with BMW sometimes is that the differences in their model range are 
so small; why offer a 435 with an 8spd auto? why not just use DCT on all 
435i? buyers who want the 435i want the full performance, just give them 
the DCT as standard; Look at Audi and MB, they pretty much standardized all 
their high performance range's gearboxes, with S tronic and the 7G AMG MCT 
speedshift. in a way it saves us the trouble of picking, which some may 
argue but i quite prefer it.
comments.author: youdame86

comments.text:
You make a good point about the DCT being the more modern gear box and it 
makes sense for the car. However the very thing you said makes no sense is 
exactly what happened, unfortunately. They released it with an 8 spd 
auto... I mean there may be other philosophy at play here. Perhaps the 8 
spd auto is better suited to in city/hwy driving, the market to whom the 
non-M division bmws are being sold. The DCT may be considered to "hardcore" 
for the average BMW
comments.author: Edward Orlando

comments.text:
Sorry bmw ,, just took a m sport 435xi out for a test... yes chris... a 
boring feel and ho hum interior.. shouldn't have to be sideways in a corner 
to enjoy a car. had 6 speed which is silky smooth and lovely clutch... but 
sedate even running to the limiter.
comments.author: David Newman

comments.text: I wish that the rear end isn't so "soft looking" but i like it :)
comments.author: jgvbadv

comments.text:
and to clarify the confusion here (many of you seem to get it wrong) the 
compact coupe/sedan segment monarchy by the German Big 3, in the order of 
Audi, BMW and MB: 1. Top performance sector: Audi RS4/RS5, BMW M3/M4, MB 
C63 AMG Coupe/Sedan/Estate 2. Semi performance sector: Audi S4/S5, BMW 
335is, MB C350 3. General public sector: A4/A5, anything 3(4)28i or below, 
MB C300 and below 4. Limited Editions: MB C63 AMG DR520 performance pack, 
M3 GTS, etc
comments.author: youdame86

comments.text:
guys, it's only the beginning of the product life cycle for 435i. 
335is/335i with M sport package did NOT get released until later on when 
the standard 335i was out on the market for some time. that being said, 
Edward I believe they will be offering DCT later on when the 435 starts 
appearing on the streets. just a matter of time when they start offering M 
packages on 435i like the E92 generation. it makes NO sense for them to 
release a new generation of the same car but with worse transmission.
comments.author: youdame86

comments.text:
I think I understand what you're looking for. Hopefully there is a 435is, 
for those that would like the DCT without the cost of a full on M4... 
however, will there be a market when the 435i equipped with the 8 spd 
automatic transmission performs so well? Of that I'm not sure. Perhaps they 
won't be able to justify building a 435is.. But for your sake I hope they 
can.
comments.author: Edward Orlando

comments.text:
That is an interesting request. I wonder... I mean there is talk of a 
possible later release of an "M435i" as different from the M4... but it 
seems as if the 435i is the "S" model (i.e. audi S5), and the 428i the 
"normal" model if you will. The 8 speed sport automatic is a good 
transmission with this car, but it looks like the only real option for a 
dual clutch gear box is a car the comes from the M division.
comments.author: Edward Orlando

No I meant the "s" model specifically. Like the current 335is, which is

No he means 435 M Performance package = The S5 wich also is like an RS

comments.text:
Lol, YOU KNOW NOTHING ABOUT THESE CARS. Stop embarrassing yourself. In what 
world does an "M packed 435i" do 0-60 in 4.4? You're as dumb as they get. 
You're taking this loss like a bitch, just shut up already with your 
nonsense. The 435 uses the same straight 6 turbo that the old 335i used, 
and it does 0-60 in 5.4 seconds. The C63 only reaches anywhere close to 
above 80k if you were to order the 507 edition, which is on a different 
performance level then the standard C63. You're beat, try again.
comments.author: Amgbenz0

comments.text:
Give up child, you know nothing about these cars and with every comment you 
post that becomes even more obvious. The 435i has a couple of features that 
the C-Class doesn't, and vice-versa. BOTH have AWD, just not the 
performance model C63, much like the M3 not having AWD either. The 4 series 
has top and side camera, and heads up display, which the C350 doesn't, but 
the C350 has a STANDARD panoramic roof and collision detection/prevention 
system, which the 4 series doesn't have even as an option.
comments.author: Amgbenz0

comments.text:
I'm not sure why people are complaining about the "ordinariness" of the 
BMW. BMW's philosophy is to be all things to all men. They provide sporty 
performance and control to the drivers of drivers, simplicity and 
refinement to those in search of luxury, and sleek classy styling for those 
who desire a good looking coupe('); best in class technology. BMW... the 
ultimate driving machine. If you don't like their philosophy, got buy an 
Audi.
comments.author: Edward Orlando

Nice performance oriented car, but as Chris said it lacks...character. It's 
so plain & normal, and for a BMW that's not right. Nothing about this car
